importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The start date of the last major government shutdown, which lasted 35 days and remains the longest in history.
The end date of the 2018–2019 shutdown, marking a 35-day period of government closure.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The current government shutdown began in 2025 and is ongoing, representing a full shutdown due to lack of appropriations bills.
The first federal government shutdown occurred in 1976, and the U.S. began formal agency directives to cease operations during funding lapses in the early 1980s.
There have been six government shutdowns since 1990, indicating a pattern of recurring political deadlock in recent decades.

keyTakeAways: The last government shutdown, from December 22, 2018, to January 25, 2019, lasted 35 days and was the longest in U.S. history.
The 2018–2019 shutdown affected approximately 800,000 federal employees, with about 300,000 furloughed and 300,000 exempted from pay and work.
The 2018 shutdown was partial, meaning only certain agencies were funded; the current shutdown is full, with no appropriations bills passed.
The current Congress has not passed any of the 12 required appropriations bills, leading to a full government shutdown.
The political environment, including narrow House majorities and lack of Senate filibuster override votes, has made resolution difficult.
A 2018 Congressional Budget Office estimate found the 2018 shutdown caused $3 billion in lost GDP.
Government shutdowns have become less common since the 1980s, but increased partisanship has made them more likely in recent decades.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. federal government is currently in a full shutdown due to Congress failing to pass any of the 12 required appropriations bills. This marks a continuation of a political stalemate, similar to the 35-day partial shutdown in 2018–2019, which was the longest in history and cost an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP. While previous shutdowns were partial and affected only some agencies, the current shutdown affects all operations. Key political obstacles include a narrow House majority and the lack of 60 Senate votes to overcome a filibuster, making legislative compromise difficult. The article highlights the economic and operational impacts, with around 800,000 federal employees affected, including furloughed and exempted workers who were not paid. The situation underscores how partisanship and structural legislative barriers contribute to prolonged government disruptions.
